Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: EAGER: Exploring the Feasibility of a Novel Thermosyphon/Heat Pipe Heat Exchanger with Low Air-Side Thermal Resistance

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1435131 / 1435233
Bergman / Faghri

The proposed research will have scientific, technological, educational, and societal impacts relevant to power plant cooling. Currently power plant cooling represents the second largest source of water withdrawl in the United States. The research forms the basis upon which current dry cooling tower technologies could be potentially transformed, leading to reduced water consumption for power plant cooling. In addition to supporting graduate students, research experiences will be provided for undergraduates. The proposed concept will also have a broad-based, beneficial impact on applications ranging from high power electronic cooling to large scale data center and server thermal management.

This collaborative exploratory effort, involving investigators at The University of Kansas and The University of Connecticut, involves the innovative integration of two-phase, closed thermosyphons or heat pipes with heat transfer augmentation techniques to develop a new heat exchanger concept with expected very low air-side thermal resistance. The heat transfer augmentation techniques include, specifically, judicious use of porous metal foams or fins on the air side of the thermosyphons. A new physics-based continuum physical model will be developed that will describe the pertinent multi-phase, multi-domain, three-dimensional transient heat transfer occurring within an integrated two-phase, closed thermosyphon heat exchanger. The heat and mass transfer effects within the two-phase, closed thermosyphon are coupled to heat transfer phenomena external to the thermosyphon-heat pipe, specifically on the air- and cooling water sides of the thermosyphon. This physics-based model will provide the necessary insight to understand the pertinent heat transfer phenomena and how they interact to reduce the overall thermal resistance of the device. The physical model will be validated by conducting a set of carefully-designed experiments.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this two-year project was to develop an experimentally validated, physics-based continuum model that describes the pertinent multi-phase, multi-domain, three-dimensional transient heat transfer occurring within a closed thermosyphon (or heat pipe) heat exchange device. Of specific interest is the beneficial effect of adding metal fins and/or metal foams to the exterior of heat pipes in order to boost thermal performance significantly.

 

Thermosyphons and heat pipes offer extremely high heat carrying capability, operate passively, consume no energy, are reliable, and are of low cost. They are used broadly in applications ranging from (a) cooling of electronics gear, to (b) potentially cooling electric power generating plants using air as the coolant instead of evaporating water. Air cooling of electric power generation stations could reduce the huge amount of water that is currently lost to evaporation, providing relief in drought-stricken regions and favorably impacting, for example, food production.

 

The experimentally validated, physics-based models that were developed with this funding are thoroughly reported in the 6 journal articles that have been published. Importantly, the new models reduce guesswork in engineering design, and provide the insight necessary to develop applied engineering models that can been used to properly design large scale heat transfer systems, such as those proposed for air cooling of electric power generating plants using thermosyphons or heat pipes.

 

One domestic Mechanical Engineering Ph.D. student was supported with this funding. A total of eight domestic undergraduate students were also supported at KU. Three of the former undergraduates are currently pursuing their graduate degrees in Mechanical Engineering in California, Colorado, and Texas. Two others are enrolled in Medical School at KU. One is currently employed in industry in Florida, but plans to return to graduate school.
